componenttext: Wondering if you could, Brad, maybe update us on the composition of the subadds you expect to see in 2017. It feels like international subs are slowing maybe more than I would have expected in your U.S. just sort of regular Ray subs are actually doing quite well. And maybe you can contrast kind of where you were a year ago when you look to that 2 million to 2.2 million and where you think the contribution is as you get to at next year?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Walter, this is Brad. I'll jump in on that. And if Neil want to add something, feel free to do that, Neil. Today, on our net add, about 2/3 are coming from QuickBooks Online in the U.S, another 1/3 is coming from outside the U.S. of QBO and, of cours
componenttext: Hey, Walter, this is Brad. I'll jump in on that. And if Neil want to add something, feel free to do that, Neil. Today, on our net add, about 2/3 are coming from QuickBooks Online in the U.S, another 1/3 is coming from outside the U.S. of QBO and, of course, QuickBooks Self-Employed. We do feel the same way you do, that we believe that have more opportunity ahead of us in QuickBooks Online outside the U.S. I'm constructively dissatisfied as with our current growth rate, but that's not what about a lack of very solid plans that get me increased confidence as we look ahead. We have an increased focus on product market fit. We have really good lessons learned from this year in terms of go-to-market plans on a country-by-country basis. We've been adding incredible talents. You probably saw the announcement of Lucas Watson joining us after 17 years of global experience in Procter & Gamble and 5 years over at Google. And we just feel good about the outlook. So as we look ahead, we still feel good about with our 2 million to 2.2 million. We think there's more opportunity in the levers in both outside the U.S. with global, as well as with QBSC. And we're going to related to that. We'll talk to you more about it when we see at Investor Day, but that's sort of the headline.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brad, can you maybe update us on any changes you're seeing it in terms of attach. Any transfer there that are notable particular that QBO side with payroll payments?
componenttext: And Brad, can you maybe update us on any changes you're seeing it in terms of attach. Any transfer there that are notable particular that QBO side with payroll payments?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we can. One of the things we would say is, for us, attach is an input metric. The most important metric at the end the day is in the penetration into the base, which leads to an average revenue per customer. So on the attach rate this past quarter fo
componenttext: Yes, we can. One of the things we would say is, for us, attach is an input metric. The most important metric at the end the day is in the penetration into the base, which leads to an average revenue per customer. So on the attach rate this past quarter for new users, payroll is at 19%. Now keep in mind, that has an increasing base of QuickBooks Self-Employed. And so, as you add more self-employed customers who by definition don't have employees, you're going to have an attach rate that looks like it's going in the wrong direction. But that's actually healthy when you actually normalize it. And our payments attach was at 11%. So right now, we feel good about with those leading indicators. We think there's room to improve and we have a focus effort to do that particular the first-time user experience. But they're all moving in the direction we want, and we expect have improved attach rate as we go into next year.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And Matt, tough shoes to fill there to keep our management team. So that's been good work.
componenttext: Great. And Matt, tough shoes to fill there to keep our management team. So that's been good work.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll echo my congrats. Matt, one of the best in the business. Look forward to hearing more about your success in the business. A couple of questions for Brad and Neil. One is, can you talk a little bit more about what Lucas Watson's particular emphasis of
componenttext: I'll echo my congrats. Matt, one of the best in the business. Look forward to hearing more about your success in the business. A couple of questions for Brad and Neil. One is, can you talk a little bit more about what Lucas Watson's particular emphasis of the company is going to be? What specifically about him that attracted you? What do you think he could achieve for you guys definitely in the next 3 to 4 years? Then I have a follow-up question with respect to payments.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, happy to do that. So for us, we were looking to replace someone who's almost irreplaceable. Caroline Donnie, who has been our Chief Sales and Marketing Officer. And she's a 21-year veteran at Intuit. And she reached a chapter in her life where she wa
componenttext: Yes, happy to do that. So for us, we were looking to replace someone who's almost irreplaceable. Caroline Donnie, who has been our Chief Sales and Marketing Officer. And she's a 21-year veteran at Intuit. And she reached a chapter in her life where she wanted to step away. Both girls are now colleagues. We love her. We celebrate her and we're taking a 1-year victory lap because she let us know some time ago she was going to do that. And we began a very concerted search to look for someone who had digital experience, someone who had clear mobile experience and someone who have world-class marketing skills. And sometimes, you'll find possible market is from packages that may not have as much digital experience. So you'll find those who grew up in the digital world, but they don't really understand the platform marketing aspects. And we think we found a Rainer in Lucas. As I mentioned, 17 years at Procter & Gamble through a range of different product line, leading them across the globe. He ultimately took P&G online and lead their digital efforts. And then, from there, he was recruited away by Google and he helped monetize YouTube and more recently, has been leading their innovative global solutions around the world. So we're excited to have him as he brings both a classful marketing, as well as digital experience. And what he'll be doing is be leading our sales channels. He'll be leading the company's marketing efforts and the global country managers report directly into him. So he'll have the non-U.S. locations, and that's where his expertise will come to bare and he'll Hill work very closely with our general managers in the U.S. to try to help our global expansion.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

componenttext: Same, yes. I'm sorry, we were just looking because the attach rates for online payroll and payments. I mentioned them just a couple seconds ago. And the payroll numbers are 19%, but that includes a base of QuickBooks Self-Employed in there. And then the second is on payment is at 11%. So there's really attach rate. So I just want to make sure I heard the question correctly, Kash.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. And also, your objectives, Brad, for where would you like that to be for fiscal '17, '18 timeframe.
componenttext: Correct. And also, your objectives, Brad, for where would you like that to be for fiscal '17, '18 timeframe.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I talked about this in terms the total addressable market. We know that about half of small businesses today, except credit card, and so we think there's a nice penetration outside opportunity in payments. In payroll today, you look at the audience o
componenttext: Yes, I talked about this in terms the total addressable market. We know that about half of small businesses today, except credit card, and so we think there's a nice penetration outside opportunity in payments. In payroll today, you look at the audience of customers who have employees, and we think we've got the opportunity to drive that number up north of 30%. In terms of what we'll achieve the next 12 to 24 months, we want to continue to see sustained improvement. And so we don't have a target that we publish externally that said at the and of 12 months, we want to be here. But I can assure you that internally, we have goals and objectives to improve that number and number get them closer to the numbers I just talked about.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jesse Hulsing of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jesse Hulsing of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The total number of QuickBooks paying customers, including desktop, really inflected this year, growing, it looks like, by my calculation, something like 23%. And if you excluded the national self-employed, it was up, I think, 18%, which in the U.S. would
componenttext: The total number of QuickBooks paying customers, including desktop, really inflected this year, growing, it looks like, by my calculation, something like 23%. And if you excluded the national self-employed, it was up, I think, 18%, which in the U.S. would be pretty strong growth. I'm wondering what you think is driving that. Is it the economy? Is it share gains? Is it something else? And do you view this type of double-digit growth for total QuickBooks paying customers is sustainable moving forward?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Jesse. We feel good about that. So for those who are looking at the fact sheet. The total paying customers were up 23%. We saw healthy growth across of the board. We saw QuickBooks Online subs at 41%. We saw the desktop customers growing 8
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Jesse. We feel good about that. So for those who are looking at the fact sheet. The total paying customers were up 23%. We saw healthy growth across of the board. We saw QuickBooks Online subs at 41%. We saw the desktop customers growing 8%. If you look at those that are new to the franchising, QBO, it was north of 80%, it was 84% this quarter. And so there's just healthy growth across the board. And what's driving it is expanding the TAM. We're expanding the TAM in 3 ways the shift to cloud and mobile, more people now considering accounting software then they would have in the past so that they could come in and try it for free and then sign-up. It's actually improving their effectiveness. The second thing is helping us is we're getting the opportunity to be due to product with other product like PayPal, American Express, and so it gives us more consideration. And last but not least is global expansion, which ahs opened up tens of million of more prospects to our product we couldn't have served a couple of years ago. So that's one big bucket. It's just expanding the TAM. The second is we did see a strong repurchase cycle in desktop this year. So the desktop units rebounded, and it was primarily because of so people who are coming at the end of their 3-year cycle and they upgraded and they were able to buy the newest version of QuickBooks desktop and that gave us a little bit of bump here in the last pass of this fiscal year. But by and large, we do think this is sustainable. We've opened up with a total addressable market. We think the cloud and mobile is going to help us. And we think there will be a group of customers that will still want to be on desktop, and we plan to have a great desktop product as well.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a quick follow-up on margins. Your segment margin for Small Business was up about 500 basis points this year. I'm wondering, when you look to your implied margin guidance for FY '17, how much of that is driven by Small Business, continue to expand its
componenttext: And a quick follow-up on margins. Your segment margin for Small Business was up about 500 basis points this year. I'm wondering, when you look to your implied margin guidance for FY '17, how much of that is driven by Small Business, continue to expand its margins? And I guess, longer term, where do you think you can get small business margins, too?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jesse, this is Neil. And the line share of that improvement is really driven by the shift in ratable. And I'll tell you, as we go forward, as we reduce our hosting cost and see other changes made in our processing infrastructure, that's going to be a
componenttext: Yes, Jesse, this is Neil. And the line share of that improvement is really driven by the shift in ratable. And I'll tell you, as we go forward, as we reduce our hosting cost and see other changes made in our processing infrastructure, that's going to be an opportunity for margins expand a little bit in the Small Business space. But this is also we are were investing heavily in R&D and in go-to-market. This is a key area where we do not focus on margin percentages in the Small Business group took we are -- we have done everything we can to encourage customer growth in this area. And deeper penetration into those addressable markets you just heard Brad mentioned. So we're intentionally not encouraging the team to expand the margins necessarily in small business, but to really focus on the top line growth. And so I think what you're seeing now is really more driven by some changes we've made in our hosting infrastructure and more predominant need to shift we made from ratable last year.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

componenttext: And my congrats to Matt as well for the move to the business unit. You'll be missed. Brad, one for you just on international QuickBooks. Can you just remind us which country just came online this year. And is there anything we can talk about in terms of incremental countries as we look forward into fiscal '17?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ross. So really, the country that came online this year was France. We ended the first half of fiscal year in beta. They went to general release. And it's now up and running, and we've got to view one of the products out there and we're feeling go
componenttext: Thanks, Ross. So really, the country that came online this year was France. We ended the first half of fiscal year in beta. They went to general release. And it's now up and running, and we've got to view one of the products out there and we're feeling good with the early trajectory. And I would also say that Brazil, even though it came on at the end of last year, really start hit a stride this you. That was through an acquisition of a company called ZeroPaper. And then we introduced QuickBooks Online in Brazil. All the other countries, we've been out there for several years now. And in terms of new markets, we currently have a Rest of World strategy, where we're testing product market sit and we're looking at the download of customers looking for the product and using it. But we have not announced any new countries or any plans to expand at this point. We want to we can see that, which we have a proven product market said before we put people in the market and begin to develop it. So right now, I'd say we're focused on this half-dozen countries we're in and we have opportunity with Brazil and France to get them up to critical mass.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a quick follow-up. Obviously, this year benefited from some of the ratable revenue shifts at a very strong tax season, and that's part the reason why the growth, revenue guidance for fiscal '17 is lower. But I'm just curious. The 7 to 9 ra
componenttext: Great. And just a quick follow-up. Obviously, this year benefited from some of the ratable revenue shifts at a very strong tax season, and that's part the reason why the growth, revenue guidance for fiscal '17 is lower. But I'm just curious. The 7 to 9 range versus your double-digit sort of ambition, do you have any thoughts on when we might get back to double-digit growth on the top line, assuming that's still part of the strategic intent?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ross, well, we absolutely see that as part of our strategic intent. We share our financial principle that we believe our enduring we believe that we have our portfolio that consistent double-digit organic growth over the long term. We also hear our s
componenttext: Yes, Ross, well, we absolutely see that as part of our strategic intent. We share our financial principle that we believe our enduring we believe that we have our portfolio that consistent double-digit organic growth over the long term. We also hear our stock a lot about the first priority is to expand our categories and to grow our customer basis. And if you look at the focus on customer growth this year, you saw TurboTax Online growing 15%, you saw QBO growing 41% and even QuickBooks desktop growing at 8%. You know if we get that flywheel going our ability to monetize in this customer and to make accelerated revenue growth over time is a proven formula. So right now, our guidance is 7 to 9, given where we are. But our full intent is to continue to look for double-digit growth on a sustained basis. And I don't know, Neil, if you want to add anything to that.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's perfect, Brad. And I think, Ross, we see opportunities to grow customers faster than we might expect otherwise. We're going to go for that heavily. And I think the payoff comes when you expect to see that double-digit growth is when we
componenttext: No, I think that's perfect, Brad. And I think, Ross, we see opportunities to grow customers faster than we might expect otherwise. We're going to go for that heavily. And I think the payoff comes when you expect to see that double-digit growth is when we begin to monetize in this customers in later years. So we see a big opportunity in front of us in '17. And we've intentionally really focused on the best ways to get those customers in.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Matt. Brad, I was curious on the -- you mentioned disappointment international for QuickBooks. Could you give us an update, report on Canada any data, please, I just elaborate on the statement and some of the things you have planned going
componenttext: Congratulations, Matt. Brad, I was curious on the -- you mentioned disappointment international for QuickBooks. Could you give us an update, report on Canada any data, please, I just elaborate on the statement and some of the things you have planned going forward?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start with the disappointment first. We're pretty candid. We'll stand up in front you and share the things we feel good about and the areas we think we can improve. And when we stand up in front of you at Investor Day, I'll show you the same t
componenttext: Yes, let me start with the disappointment first. We're pretty candid. We'll stand up in front you and share the things we feel good about and the areas we think we can improve. And when we stand up in front of you at Investor Day, I'll show you the same thing I showed the Board in July, is when we have a base of 287,000 paying subs and we're growing at 45% and then you have a base of 1.5 million, when you include the U.S. and it's growing at 41%, a 400 basis point disparity in growth rate I don't believe its efficient for this side the base. We know we're capable of more. We had good products. Have the opportunity to get out there and accelerate this total addressable market and penetrated that market. So that's just the candid reality. Talk about it that way inside the company. But that said, I've got to tell, look some good momentum been built up in the U.K, early start in France and Brazil, and strong momentum in Australia. Canada has rebounded. So as we told you, our one issue we had in Canada is we have tried to sell QuickBooks Online in a box in a retail store. It was an experiment we had tried in the U.S. that didn't work and we shouted out but let it going Canada a little while longer. So the same sort of attrition issues. And so we pulled it out and we created a grow over a problem. That's now in our rearview mirror. So Canada's moving the right direction. India is the one that were trying to develop a model that shifts away from the accountants and focuses directly on Small Business and then looks for ways to monetize that over the long term. And we're running a series of experiments in India, but this is a very small part the base. But that's the one that I would tell you that we still have several alternatives we're exploring, but we don't have the go-to-market model figured out in India yet. So that's how I feel about overall global. I don't want to paint a black picture over this. I think there's really shining areas but when you put it all together, 287,000 paid subs growth at 45%, I know we're capable of more and our aspirations are to accelerate that performance.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

So just thinking going forward about capital allocation. China's been a bunch of small talk and by telling acquisition. How should we think going forward just on the strategy?

componenttext: Yes, Scott, I think we're going to continue to look for opportunities to build on our product roadmap, to add feature functionality and add new technology. Really across of the board. Some of it internal that views of things like privacy and security and infrastructure management. Some delivering feature functional like we've talked about in the past. But we've proven adding teams and adding technology really accelerates our product development cycle. And so we're taking to do that. You'll probably -- you'll continue to hear about activities in that space. They are typically relatively small. And so it's not a big commitment on our overall capital planning. But our -- as you saw, our CapEx guidance for 2017 is back to more normalized levels. The cash flow generation the company is very strong. And so we're comfortable that we've got many of them to do the acquisitions we need to fund this increase in the dividend of 13% and continue to be active in share repurchase as well.

componenttext: Yes. So let me take this, John, and then Neil and I can tag team. I'll start first with LTV to TAC which lifetime value cost to acquire a customer. We all know what the metric for fast business. And in the U.S, our LTV to TAC is north of 5.5%. So it's a very healthy number with an opportunity to continue to improve as we become more efficient. Outside the U.S, is we're building the market and we're building out our brand, our LTV to TAC is not at that level but it continues to improve with cohort of customers we bring on. And so we have an overall look at that we felt was an LTV to CAC as we try to expand its new geographies and try to absorb it the customer base growth but in terms of QPSC, do not believe that we have reported or talked about LTV to CAC.

componenttext: No, it's not. Right.

Is it fair to say that you guys are keeping your options open regarding your spend? Or are there some other dynamics in the that's kind of keeping your to ensure that wide for the year?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Yun, for the question. Let me step out of talked about that for a minute bit because we have a philosophy that will update our guidance when we have our change in our outlook. And right now, there is no change in our outlook. We've been tr
componenttext: Yes, thank you, Yun, for the question. Let me step out of talked about that for a minute bit because we have a philosophy that will update our guidance when we have our change in our outlook. And right now, there is no change in our outlook. We've been trying to message for some time that our goal is to deprive subscriber growth north of 40% and our QBO ecosystem revenue growth between 25% and 30%. And this quarter, once again, showed that we were in those ZIP codes. So we didn't feel them to go out and change the guidance we have provided a year ago on the fall. But I do want to remind us that when we first set guidance for QBO subs a year ago at Investor Day, the number has been 2 million in 2017. And last fall, we said we're going to move it from 2 million, from 2 to 2.2 million. If you kind of took our current trajectory and you do the 40% growth rate of approaches squarely at the middle of that guidance range and we'll talk to you at invested about levers were looking at around global expand -- or excuse me, global growth, QBSC and other things that can move us up in that guidance range. But since there is nothing meaningfully different, we did not want to change the guidance and signal everything that quite frankly, haven't changed.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add, Brad, if I could just add. The cost of acquisition cost is really nothing constraint between the low-end and high-end the range. We to measure very rigorously our acquisition costs by channel and by market bluntly we have opportunities t
componenttext: I would just add, Brad, if I could just add. The cost of acquisition cost is really nothing constraint between the low-end and high-end the range. We to measure very rigorously our acquisition costs by channel and by market bluntly we have opportunities to bring in customers that are going to be profitable over the long term, we have plenty of resources and we're more than willing to invest in those. And when we pull back investments because we had concerns about the quality of the sub long-term or about the ability to stick with us over lovebird of time, we really monetize at the rate we expected. But we are more than ready to invest when we see a channel, a product opportunity or market that's really going gang buster. So the investment level or the resource allocations are not a governing factor in the resource range at all. It really is a factor the opportunity size without effective are being with our product. Customization a localization for the market and our go-to-market campaigns.

componenttext: Yes. Kartik, every year, as you know, it gets highly competitive in the tax arena. And I would anticipate another season like that. I think that we have great competition. componenttext: And then as you look at your guidance for FY '17 on the tax side, what would you anticipate in terms of mix and price? I'm assuming you would anticipate greater volume than price. But I'm just interested how you break that 58% down?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Kartik, as you know, we have are pretty consistent rule of thumb, which is to expand the category and grow our share and grow our customers faster than we grow our revenue. And so really, nothing has changed there. We're in the fourth year near -- a
componenttext: Well, Kartik, as you know, we have are pretty consistent rule of thumb, which is to expand the category and grow our share and grow our customers faster than we grow our revenue. And so really, nothing has changed there. We're in the fourth year near -- at fourth year now of a multiyear journey to basically get taxes done with little to no effort at all. And we've been putting a lot of innovation into the product. Last year, there were 2 dozen innovations we introduced in TurboTax. The typical year was 6. That platform is in place. And we anticipate, as may or even more innovative new ideas going into the products this coming season. So it's really going to be about the product doing a better job in its growing our customer base. We're not going to rely and pricing increases and we just going to like to continue to expand the category in grocery.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

componenttext: Then just one last question. Neil. As you look at the upcoming year. You talked about investment and obviously growing QBO clients ad tax clients, I'm wondering at what point would you say you'd want to increase the investment? What would you have to see to say we should increase the investment because in the long run, that will be beneficial for Intuit?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as you can imagine, Kartik, we have assumptions internally about the growth we expect in terms of customer so that's the play to the revenue that we're guiding and they expect -- and expenses that we are setting aside. If we see those customer growt
componenttext: Well, as you can imagine, Kartik, we have assumptions internally about the growth we expect in terms of customer so that's the play to the revenue that we're guiding and they expect -- and expenses that we are setting aside. If we see those customer growth rate expand faster than we expected, we see investments playing off then we have opportunities to reallocate within the company and put dollars were did getting the best return and the best outlook. I think we have a pretty rigorous process, though, of reallocating internally to things that are working really well and dialing back things that are not generating what we expected when we build the plan together. So we have an internal process. I think works pretty well. We look at the customer growth and how we're doing with revenue per customer quite frequently. LTV to CAC, Brad has already mentioned. And so we have opportunities to adjust and reallocate money that we're going to spend internally pretty frequently throughout the year and we do that, as a matter of fact.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations, Matt. Brad, you mentioned that there was a bit of a refresh cycle in terms of the desktop side. I'm kind of curious, what do you think at this point is the major gaining factor that prevented a bigger portion of those desktop users to mov
componenttext: Congratulations, Matt. Brad, you mentioned that there was a bit of a refresh cycle in terms of the desktop side. I'm kind of curious, what do you think at this point is the major gaining factor that prevented a bigger portion of those desktop users to moving to online?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Sterling, I would say, first of all, there really isn't a major gaining factor other than their willingness to adopt to cloud. In fact, the number of migrations to move from desktop to QuickBooks Online this year within their own customer base was up
componenttext: Yes, Sterling, I would say, first of all, there really isn't a major gaining factor other than their willingness to adopt to cloud. In fact, the number of migrations to move from desktop to QuickBooks Online this year within their own customer base was up 25%. So we've done work with our customer base and the desktop to figure out why they aren't interested in the cloud. And reasons 1 through 5 are all basically, I'm not ready to move to the cloud provider want to put my data into the quality the want to move to subscription basis. Maker product is working just fine. ProTax on it is working with me in the been a desktop version. Those are the kinds of reasons. In fact, only 14% side feature parity. So we want to make sure we keep this customers in the franchise we want to continue to make that got a comfortable with using the cloud version and we want to continue to let them know that we can help the migrates to the cloud when they're ready. As long as they stay with Intuit, we're happy. But right now, that's sort of bucket 1, which is there really aren't any major barriers other than their mindset and comfort level with the cloud. The second side is the repurchase cycle. We see this happen. Last year, we had raised the price on desktop. We did it for the first half of the year thinking that might actually drive people into the cloud what we now realize is there wasn't issue, it was a mindset. And so when we brought it back down total more normalized promotion we started to see the regular repurchase type will happen again and that's what carried into this year. So I think what we see is a group the people will probably delete in that great last year. And in this year, they come back in on a normal rhythm.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

componenttext: That makes sense. And then just one follow-up on the tax side, given we are in an election year, so there anything that you're seeing out of either party that you think would have a material impact to the positive or the negative on your tax franchise?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sterling, at this point, we just want to remain focused on working with whoever ends up winning the election. We're big supporters of tax simplification. That's the business we're and. We are big supporters of voluntary compliance, which is helping people
componenttext: Sterling, at this point, we just want to remain focused on working with whoever ends up winning the election. We're big supporters of tax simplification. That's the business we're and. We are big supporters of voluntary compliance, which is helping people voluntarily filed our taxes and it's the government disagrees, let the government contests that. And at the end the day, we want to make sure we're helping people keep their hard earned dollars in their pocket. Only pay the stuff that they owe the government. And so whether it's our puzzle are at the applicant or independent go have a lead working well both sizes or to be sure that we keep those 3 things front and center.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about accelerating Small Business growth rates. I is some of that has to do with better monetization but maybe you could talk a little bit more about how you -- how that's going to work.
componenttext: You talked about accelerating Small Business growth rates. I is some of that has to do with better monetization but maybe you could talk a little bit more about how you -- how that's going to work.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jim. I think, first of all, it has to do with both customers and monetization. On the customers side, while we continue to see strong growth in QBO in the U.S, we believe we have outside opportunity with better execution, stronger product market fit
componenttext: Sure, Jim. I think, first of all, it has to do with both customers and monetization. On the customers side, while we continue to see strong growth in QBO in the U.S, we believe we have outside opportunity with better execution, stronger product market fit and just a continued learning curve outside the U.S. And also, we're in the early days of QuickBooks Self-Employed. 85,000 paying subs now versus 25,000 12 months ago. And we really learned a lot this year as we put the bundled together with TurboTax we went after people like the Uber drivers and lift driver. And we think there's a lot of opportunity to grow the customer base and then when you get to the monetization of there is an opportunity there and we can see the tailwind at our back where we can fill the Telenet our back rather. One is, we see opportunities to continue to improve attached. The second is, as of those customers move off of promotional pricing and they hit their 13th month, the average revenue per customer goes up about 50%. And the third is we did just pass through a modest price increase in QuickBooks Online. It's gone out to the new customers and were in the process of rolling it out to existing base of those three things combined help us drive in the average revenue per customer, which helps to drive the QBO revenue. So it's those 2 things that we see continuing to drive improved performance in QBO.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And overall, ProConnect, could you remind me why you're expecting a decline next year and kind of what you expect maybe longer-term for ProConnect?
componenttext: Great. And overall, ProConnect, could you remind me why you're expecting a decline next year and kind of what you expect maybe longer-term for ProConnect?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can. I'll start first with the strategic role ProConnect plays in the business. In the covenants are not only the key to small businesses making their accounting, payroll and payments decisions so they have a very important role to help us both in
componenttext: Yes, I can. I'll start first with the strategic role ProConnect plays in the business. In the covenants are not only the key to small businesses making their accounting, payroll and payments decisions so they have a very important role to help us both in Small Business and help them be successful. But probably they have a business that they monetize but they to tax returns for consumers and small businesses. And we are laser focus on the multiservice. Those are the people who do both books and taxes, not only for consumers, but also for small businesses. And that's a very large population. So one of the things that we've chosen to do is we step back and said, let's look at how we lined up our products and pricing to better serve these customers. And some other requires us building better collaboration between QuickBooks and their tax products. And so we're in the process of building that R&D out. And some of it is we needed to stop pricing for every single piece that we were giving the accountants. So for example, busy, we've chosen to give QuickBooks Online for accountants to the accountants for free. We don't charge them. Another thing we choose to do this year is not to take a price increase at the normal level as we would on the tax products. And instead, we're starting to build that into that kind product. So stop taking price everywhere we historically dead. And as a result of that, we're kind of backing off on the revenue growth short term on the ProTax back the house and we think long-term that's going to accelerate the overall revenue growth for the company.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I got it. Thank you so much work. I appreciate the clarification. Well, first of all, one of the piece of the good news is anyone who is in the desktop Pru advisor network is also now in the cloud network. So we gave them a cloud packaged. Witching them.
componenttext: I got it. Thank you so much work. I appreciate the clarification. Well, first of all, one of the piece of the good news is anyone who is in the desktop Pru advisor network is also now in the cloud network. So we gave them a cloud packaged. Witching them. Certified to them and they're increasingly recommending that customers use QuickBooks Online. In fact, the last number I saw, we were north of 600,000 accountants who had at least 1 customer on QBO. And then those who actually have 3 plus customers have more than doubled in the last 12 months. And we see those as great leading indicators of not only cloud adoption on the accounting side, but then recommending it to their clients. So that's one thing, which is desktop broad vice have come along with us. The second is our pride Pfizer program is a global program. So we're in morning our guidance in all the countries. And as I think you alluded to in your question, in some countries, the guidance recommendations carries even more weight than it does in the U.S. There are some countries where, for example, France, the accountants is the end all and be all in terms of making the final decision on whether this product is ready for a Small Business client to use. So we partner very closely with those accounting professionals to make sure that they feel good, they're certified and they're endorsing our products. So by and large, what he sees on a case-by-case basis, this cloud-based product is available to desktop, is available to all the countries. We have a similar approach but we work with those local accounting professionals to make shoe boots they need so the channel endorse it with their clients.

componenttext: Sure, I think Brad has mentioned to you and just talked about, as customers are maturing in the QBO online ecosystem for coming out promotional pricing. And our attach has improved a little bit. So it's a small increase. And honestly, we would prefer to see the customers growing really faster. So this is kind of unintended consequence, Reyna, to be honest with you. I think the moral -- and the healthier statistic want to terms is a see the customer growth accelerate. But that's the main driver between the improvement you see in the fourth quarter, is just more of this customers coming off. We had a couple the quarters a year ago, which meant that in the late third quarter, early fourth quarter, you had a little bit more customers than usual coming out that promotional period and paying the full price. That's just an indication that retention rate are holding up quite nicely as those customers did come off that promotional pricing. Once debuts the product for longer than a few months, they're pretty sticky.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, sir. Good afternoon, and welcome to Intuit's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Conference Call. I'm here with Brad Smith, our Chairman and CEO; and Neil Williams, our CFO. Now before we start, I'd like to remind everyone that our remarks will includ
componenttext:
Thank you, sir. Good afternoon, and welcome to Intuit's Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2016 Conference Call. I'm here with Brad Smith, our Chairman and CEO; and Neil Williams, our CFO. 
Now before we start, I'd like to remind everyone that our remarks will include forward-looking statements. There are a number of factors that could cause Intuit's results to differ materially from our expectations. You can learn more about these risks in the press release we issued earlier this afternoon, our Form 10-K for fiscal 2015 and our other SEC filings. All of those documents are available on the Investor Relations page of Intuit's website at intuit.com. We assume no obligation to update any forward-looking statement.
Some of the numbers in this report are presented on a non-GAAP basis. We've reconciled the comparable GAAP and non-GAAP numbers in today's press release. Unless otherwise noted, all growth rates refer to the current period versus the comparable prior year period, and the business metrics and associated growth rates refer to worldwide business metrics.
Also, all reported results and guidance except GAAP net income and EPS exclude Demandforce, QuickBase and Quicken, which have been sold and reclassified to discontinued operations. 
A copy of our prepared remarks and supplemental financial information will be available on our website after this call ends. 
And finally, I'm excited to let you all know that I'll soon be moving to Texas to lead finance for our ProConnect business. Therefore, today will be my last earnings call in the investor relations seat. It's been a pleasure working with you all over the past 6 years, and I'll leave you in good hands. Jerry Natoli will continue to head up investor relations following my transition in early September. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Brad Smith.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Matt, and thanks for an amazing 6 years in the investor relations seat. I got to tell you, we are super excited to see the impact you're going to have in our ProConnect business going forward.
componenttext: All right. Thank you, Matt, and thanks for an amazing 6 years in the investor relations seat. I got to tell you, we are super excited to see the impact you're going to have in our ProConnect business going forward.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad.
componenttext: Thanks, Brad.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I'll tell you, we had an excellent finish to the fiscal year. For the fourth quarter, we delivered revenue of $754 million, which was up 8%. We've continued to build on our momentum throughout the ye
componenttext:
Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us. I'll tell you, we had an excellent finish to the fiscal year. For the fourth quarter, we delivered revenue of $754 million, which was up 8%. We've continued to build on our momentum throughout the year with fiscal 2016 revenue coming in at $4.7 billion, up 12%. 
Let me begin by sharing a few reflections on our business performance, and I'll start with Small Business.
With the shift to the cloud and mobile solutions, the opening of our platform to enable third parties to connect and our expansion into new geographies outside the U.S., we have more than doubled our total addressable market. Our primary goal is to penetrate this large addressable market, growing our customer base and expanding share in every geography. 
Our Small Business ecosystem remains vibrant, with total QuickBooks Online subscribers growing 41% this year to more than 1.5 million subs. We added more than 400,000 QuickBooks Online subscribers over the past 12 months. We're leaning in to new offerings like QuickBooks Self-Employed while continuing to post strong growth in QuickBooks Online overall. We finished the year with about 85,000 self-employed subscribers, which is up from 25,000 just 1 year ago. Outside the U.S., QuickBooks Online grew 45% to 287,000 paying subs. In short, QuickBooks Online continues on a strong trajectory, and we're executing well against the consistent set of priorities. We're realizing our goal to be the operating system behind small business success, helping small businesses save time and money so they can thrive when times are good, and they can remain resilient when times are tough. We're also delivering outstanding results against our other strategic goal: to do the nations' taxes. 
For the fiscal year, Consumer Tax revenue grew 10%, with TurboTax Online units growing 15% and total TurboTax units growing 12%. We performed extremely well this past year, introducing 2 dozen innovations in TurboTax, which helps expand the do-it-yourself software category while increasing our share in the category as well. We fully anticipate another competitive tax season next year, and our teams are already hard at work building on the next wave of innovations at a pace that promises to exceed this year's. 
On the ProConnect side, revenue came in as expected at $428 million. Our ProConnect team is continuing to increase the focus on multiservice accountants. Those are accountants who do both books and taxes for their clients. This is in service to driving those accounting firms' success as well as growing our own Small Business ecosystem.
To sum it up, fiscal 2016 was a strong year from start to finish. The QuickBooks Online ecosystem is driving Small Business growth, and our tax businesses are celebrating a successful season. We're heading into fiscal 2017 with the wind at our backs, and we have some exciting plans under way as we look ahead.
So with that, let me turn it over to Neil to walk you through the financial details.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good afternoon, everyone. For the fourth quarter, we delivered revenue of $754 million, up 8%; non-GAAP operating income of $36 million; a GAAP operating loss of $56 million; non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.08; and a GAAP loss
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good afternoon, everyone. For the fourth quarter, we delivered revenue of $754 million, up 8%; non-GAAP operating income of $36 million; a GAAP operating loss of $56 million; non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.08; and a GAAP loss per share of $0.16. 
For the full year, we delivered revenue of $4.7 billion, up 12%; non-GAAP operating income of $1.6 billion, up 36%; GAAP operating income of $1.2 billion, up 68%; non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $3.78, up 46%; and GAAP diluted earnings per share of $3.69, up from $1.28 a year ago. 
As a reminder, our GAAP results for fiscal 2015 and 2016 reflect the decision to divest certain businesses in fiscal 2015 and the sale of those businesses in fiscal 2016. You can refer to our press release for more details. 
Turning to the business segments. Total Small Business segment revenue grew 10% for the quarter and 9% for the year. QuickBooks Online subscriber growth finished the year strong at 41%, as we cross the high end of our guidance to finish with 1,513,000 paid subs. Small Business Online Ecosystem revenue grew 25% for the full year, and we expect some acceleration in fiscal 2017. 
Within the online ecosystem, our payroll and payments businesses posted healthy growth for the year. Online Payroll customers grew 17%, online active payment customers grew 6%, and online payments charge volume grew 15%.
And while QuickBooks Online is driving the majority of our new customer acquisition, QuickBooks Desktop remains a resilient and important part of the business. Desktop units grew 14% in the quarter and 8% for the year as we saw a bump-up in customer upgrades. Roughly 2/3 of the desktop units we sold in fiscal 2016 were upgrades as opposed to new units. New desktop customers were essentially flat year-over-year. Total Small Business desktop ecosystem revenue grew 4% for the year. For fiscal 2017, we expect units to decline modestly and desktop ecosystem revenue to be flat to up slightly.
Moving over to tax. Consumer Tax revenue grew 10% for the year. As Brad said, we will continue to invest in the product experience and to prioritize growth in customers above margin expansion. 
ProConnect revenue grew 51% for the year due to changes in our offerings that resulted in lower ratable revenue recognition in fiscal 2015. As I mentioned on the earnings call in May, we expect ProConnect revenue to be roughly flat in fiscal 2017.
We continue to take a disciplined approach to capital management, investing the cash we generate in opportunities that yield a return on investment greater than 15%. With approximately $1.1 billion in cash and investments on our balance sheet, our first priority is investing for customer growth. 
When it's the best use of cash, we'll return cash to our share holders via share repurchases. In fiscal 2016, we repurchased $2.3 billion worth of shares at an average price of $91. We reduced our weighted average share count by 7% net in fiscal 2016, and we expect to be in the market consistently in fiscal 2017. We have a total of $2.4 billion on our repurchase authorization, including $2 billion recently approved by our board.
Our plans include a cash dividend of up to $1.36 per share for fiscal 2017, with the first quarter dividend of $0.34 per share payable on October 18. This represents a 13% increase versus last year and reflects our confidence in our business strategy as well as more recurring and predictable revenue streams. You can find guidance details in our press release and on our fact sheet. 
Here are the highlights for fiscal 2017: QuickBooks Online subscribers of 2 million to 2.2 million, growth of 32% to 45%; revenue of $5 billion to $5.1 billion, growth of 7% to 9%; non-GAAP operating income of $1.675 billion to $1.725 billion, growth of 8% to 11%; GAAP operating income of $1.33 billion to $1.38 billion, growth of 7% to 11%; non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $4.30 to $4.40 for growth of 14% to 16%; GAAP diluted earnings per share of $3.35 to $3.45 versus $3.69 in fiscal 2016. Fiscal 2016 earnings per share includes $0.65 net income per share from discontinued operations. 
We feel confident in our ability to deliver against our financial principles and our long-term strategic goals, and we look forward to sharing our progress with you throughout this fiscal year. 
On a personal note, we will miss Matt's outstanding contribution in investor relations. We are very fortunate to be adding his experience and business acumen to our ProConnect Group as we strengthen the connection between our accountant community and our Small Business ecosystem. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Brad.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Neil. To recap, we are pleased with our fiscal 2016 results, and I'm encouraged by our trajectory, our trajectory in Small Business as we continue to grow QuickBooks Online in the U.S. and in our prioritized markets around the globe.
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Neil. To recap, we are pleased with our fiscal 2016 results, and I'm encouraged by our trajectory, our trajectory in Small Business as we continue to grow QuickBooks Online in the U.S. and in our prioritized markets around the globe. At the same time, we're expanding the category by solving new customer problems with QuickBooks Self-Employed. 
Our tax businesses had another strong year, turning up the innovation machine to compete effectively in the marketplace. We look forward to building on this success in fiscal 2017. We'll talk more about these priorities and our strategy to execute against them at our Investor Day, which we're going to be holding on our Mountain View campus on September 21. We look forward to seeing all of you there. 
And with that, let's open it up to you to hear what's on your mind. So Latif, I'll get it back to you.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats, Matt, on the new role. Brad and Neil, on the operating margin side, you had a really solid year of operating margin improvement, up over 700 basis points year-over-year. The guidance implies a much slower rate of operating margin improvement. Ca
componenttext: Congrats, Matt, on the new role. Brad and Neil, on the operating margin side, you had a really solid year of operating margin improvement, up over 700 basis points year-over-year. The guidance implies a much slower rate of operating margin improvement. Can you talk a little bit about why that is, where you're spending?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brent. Happy to. You have to factor in the effective ratable on the improvement increase of '16 over '15. But I'll tell you, the thing I feel really good about in our '17 outlook is the amount of money that we are putting into the product itself to
componenttext: Sure, Brent. Happy to. You have to factor in the effective ratable on the improvement increase of '16 over '15. But I'll tell you, the thing I feel really good about in our '17 outlook is the amount of money that we are putting into the product itself to improve the product experience in the markets where we're focused. Really nice go-to-market plans and programs there to capitalize on the TAM opportunity we see before us, and I think we've given ourselves some good opportunities on the revenue side by not focusing on price increase to drive revenue growth. The revenue growth that you're going to see in 2017 is largely driven by customer growth and customer accounts, and as you saw this year in Consumer Tax in 2016, we think they're just big opportunities to grow our customer base and continue to expand. So I think the margin expansion you're going to see in 2017 is going to be very well balanced between investments to drive growth and product improvements and also a very reasonable approach on the pricing side.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Brent, this is Brad. Just to add to Neil's thoughtful answer around where the investments are going, the other thing that we feel good about is when we moved to ratable in 2015, we provided a long-term guidance. We would return margins back to th
componenttext: Yes. And Brent, this is Brad. Just to add to Neil's thoughtful answer around where the investments are going, the other thing that we feel good about is when we moved to ratable in 2015, we provided a long-term guidance. We would return margins back to the mid-30s in 2017. And so with all those investments that Neil's talking about, we are going to be coming in where we said we would several years ago. So we feel very good we have a very strong business model that continues to get operating margin expansion. But at the same time, we continue to invest for the long-term growth.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

componenttext: I'm wondering if you could, Brad, maybe update us on the composition of the sub adds that you expect to see in 2017. It feels like your international subs are slowing maybe more than I would have expected, and your U.S. just sort of regular weight [ph] subs are actually doing quite well. And maybe you could contrast kind of where you were a year ago when you look to that 2 million to 2.2 million and where you think the contribution is as you get to it next year.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Walter, this is Brad. I'll jump in on that. And then if Neil wants to add something, feel free to do that, Neil. Today, on our net adds, about 2/3 are coming from QuickBooks Online in the U.S. Another 1/3 is coming from outside the U.S. of QBO and, of cou
componenttext: Walter, this is Brad. I'll jump in on that. And then if Neil wants to add something, feel free to do that, Neil. Today, on our net adds, about 2/3 are coming from QuickBooks Online in the U.S. Another 1/3 is coming from outside the U.S. of QBO and, of course, QuickBooks Self-Employed. We do feel the same way you do that we believe we have more opportunity ahead of us in QuickBooks Online outside the U.S. I'm constructively dissatisfied as obtained with our current growth rate, but that's not without a lack of very solid plans that give me increased confidence as we look ahead. We have an increased focus on product/market fit. We have really good lessons learned from this year in terms of go-to-market plans on a country-by-country basis. We've been adding incredible talents. You probably saw the announcement of Lucas Watson joining us after 17 years of global experience at Procter & Gamble and 5 years over at Google. And we just feel good about the outlook. So as we look ahead, we still feel good about our 2 million to 2.2 million. We think there's more opportunity in the levers in both outside the U.S. with global as well as with QBSE. And we're going to leaning into that. And we'll talk to you more about it when we see at Investor Day, but that's sort of the headline.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Brad, can you maybe update us on any changes you're seeing in terms of attach? Any trends there that are notable, particularly on the QBO side with payroll and payments?
componenttext: And Brad, can you maybe update us on any changes you're seeing in terms of attach? Any trends there that are notable, particularly on the QBO side with payroll and payments?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we can. One of the things we would say is, for us, attach is an input metric. The most important metric at the end the day is the penetration into the base, which leads to an average revenue per customer. So on the attach rates this past quarter for
componenttext: Yes, we can. One of the things we would say is, for us, attach is an input metric. The most important metric at the end the day is the penetration into the base, which leads to an average revenue per customer. So on the attach rates this past quarter for new users, payroll is at 19%. Now keep in mind, that has an increasing base of QuickBooks Self-Employed. And so as you add more self-employed customers who, by definition, don't have employees, you're going to have an attach rate that looks like it's going in the wrong direction. But that's actually healthy when you actually normalize it. And our payments attach was at 11%. So right now, we feel good with those leading indicators. We think there's room to improve, and we have a focused effort to do that, particularly with the first-time use experience. But they're all moving in the direction we want, and we expect to have improved attach rates as we go into next year.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Kash Rangan of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

componenttext: I'll echo my congrats, Matt, one of the best in the business. Look forward to hearing more about your success in the business works [ph]. A couple of questions for Brad and Neil. One is, can you talk a little bit more about what Lucas Watson's particular emphasis of the company is going to be? What specifically about him attracted you? What do you think he could achieve for you guys definitely in the next 3 to 4 years? And then I have a follow-up question with respect to payments.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kash, happy to do that. So for us, we were looking to replace someone who's almost irreplaceable. Caroline Donahue has been our Chief Sales and Marketing Officer, and she's a 21-year veteran of Intuit. And she reached a chapter in her life where she
componenttext: Yes. Kash, happy to do that. So for us, we were looking to replace someone who's almost irreplaceable. Caroline Donahue has been our Chief Sales and Marketing Officer, and she's a 21-year veteran of Intuit. And she reached a chapter in her life where she wanted to step away. Both girls are now at college. We love her. We celebrate her, and we're taking a 1-year victory lap because she let us know some time ago she was going to do that. And we began a very concerted search to look for someone who had digital experience, someone who had clear mobile experience and someone who have world-class marketing skills. And sometimes you'll find classical marketers from packaged goods who may not have as much digital experience. Or you'll find those who grew up in the digital world, but they don't really understand the platform marketing aspects. And we think we found a Rainer [ph] in Lucas, as I mentioned, 17 years at Procter & Gamble through a range of different product lines, leading them across the globe. He ultimately took P&G online and led their digital efforts. And then from there, he was recruited away by Google, and he helped monetize YouTube and, more recently, has been leading their innovative global solutions around the world. And so we're excited to have him because he brings both that classical marketing as well as digital experience. And what he'll be doing is be leading our sales channels. He'll be leading the company's marketing efforts, and the global country managers report directly into him. So he'll have the non-U.S. locations, and that's where his expertise will come to bare. And he'll work very closely with our general managers in the U.S. to try to help our global expansion.
