componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Latif, and I will be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Intuit's First Quarter 2017 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] .
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Jerry Natoli, Intuit's Vice President of Finance and Treasurer. Mr. Natoli?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Latif. Good afternoon, and welcome to Intuit's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. I'm here with Brad Smith, our Chairman and CEO; and Neil Williams, our CFO.Before we start, I'd like to remind everyone that our remarks will include forwa
componenttext:
Thanks, Latif. Good afternoon, and welcome to Intuit's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. I'm here with Brad Smith, our Chairman and CEO; and Neil Williams, our CFO.
Before we start, I'd like to remind everyone that our remarks will include forward-looking statements. There are a number of factors that could cause Intuit's results to differ materially from our expectations. You can learn more about these risks in the press release we issued earlier this afternoon, our Form 10-K for fiscal 2016 and our other SEC filings. All of those documents are available on the Investor Relations page of Intuit's website at intuit.com. We assume no obligation to update any forward-looking statement.
Some of the numbers in this remarks are presented on a non-GAAP basis. We've reconciled the comparable GAAP and non-GAAP numbers in today's press release. Unless otherwise noted, all growth rates refer to the current period versus the comparable prior year period, and the business metrics and associated growth rates refer to worldwide business metrics.
A copy of our prepared remarks and supplemental financial information will be available on our website after this call ends. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Brad.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Jerry. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Fiscal 2017 is off to a strong start, and we're building on the momentum that we developed in fiscal 2016. In the first quarter, we grew revenue 9%, exceeded our QuickBook
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Jerry. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Fiscal 2017 is off to a strong start, and we're building on the momentum that we developed in fiscal 2016. 
In the first quarter, we grew revenue 9%, exceeded our QuickBooks Online subscriber guidance and we beat our overall financial targets. With that backdrop, let me begin by sharing a few reflections on our business performance, and I'll start with Small Business. 
QuickBooks Online continue to gain traction as we pursue a large global market opportunity. Our goal remains to be the operating system behind Small Business success, helping small businesses save time and improve their cash flow, so that they thrive when times are good and they remain resilient when times are tough.
Total QBO subscribers grew 41% in the quarter to more than 1.6 million subs. We drove acceleration in our Small Business market outside the U.S., where QuickBooks Online grew 50% to 323,000 subscribers, up from 45% in fiscal 2016. The increase came in Canada, the U.K. and Australia with subscriber growth in the U.K. accelerating to 87%, which was up from 78%. We continue to focus our efforts on improving the product market fit in the remaining countries, which include India, Brazil and France, and we'll report more on our progress with these efforts in the coming quarters. 
QuickBooks Self-Employed is also contributing to the acceleration of subscribers. Roughly 110,000 of our QBO subscribers are using QuickBooks Self-Employed. This is compared to 85,000 last quarter and 35,000 a year ago. We've now launched QuickBooks Self-Employed in the U.K. and in Australia as well. 
I'm encouraged by the start in our Small Business Group, but I also expect our momentum to continue accelerating in the second half as we drive towards our QBO subscriber target of 2 million to 2.2 million subs for the full fiscal year. I'm confident in this acceleration because of the innovation that we have coming to market, including improvements in the core QBO platform that simplify the first use experience, including enabling small businesses to generate their first profit and loss statement in less than 5 minutes. 
We've also introduced a new smart invoicing capability that allows for real-time tracking of the invoice status in both QuickBooks Online and QuickBooks Self-Employed. We've also enhanced the QuickBooks Self-Employed user experience with the ability to now receive payments on mobile devices and always on mileage tracking. And finally, our recently introduced partnership with Google enable the seamless integration between QuickBooks Online and Google Calendar. 
Based on the strong product market fit that we have with Canada, the U.K. and Australia, we're leaning into greater go-to-market activity behind QBO in these countries. It's these factors that support our confidence in the continued acceleration of QBO subscribers in the back half of the fiscal year.
With that overview on Small Business, let's talk tax. We're gearing up for another exciting tax season in TurboTax by continuing our multiyear investment and product innovation. Those product innovations are focused on reimagining the tax preparation process while driving customer growth and increasing market share. We also continue to promote a set of best practices and standards within the industry that enable the IRS and the state to improve the ability to combat tax fraud. 
In ProConnect, we're focused on serving multiservice accountants to do both books and taxes for their customers. Our goal is to be the operating system behind the accountant's successes as well. In service to this goal, we're providing one location within QuickBooks Online for accountant, where the accountant can access all of their workflows.
Several exciting innovations are underway to begin to leverage the capabilities that we've developed in TurboTax within our accountant's offering, including increasing the number of documents that can be automatically uploaded, which reduces data entry. 
We expect these innovations to help us further strengthen our accountant relationships by helping drive QuickBooks growth over time. So across the board, we're off to a strong start in all of our businesses. And with that, let me turn it over to Neil to walk you through the financials.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good afternoon, everyone. For the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we delivered revenue of $778 million, up 9%; GAAP operating loss of $61 million; non-GAAP operating income of $32 million; a GAAP loss per share of $0.12; and non-GAAP dilut
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good afternoon, everyone. For the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we delivered revenue of $778 million, up 9%; GAAP operating loss of $61 million; non-GAAP operating income of $32 million; a GAAP loss per share of $0.12; and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.06. Note that our GAAP earnings per share includes the impact of the early adoption of the new accounting standard update for share-based compensation. This update requires excess tax benefits realized upon the settlement of a share-based compensation award to flow through the earning statement instead of the balance sheet.
We expect this accounting change to reduce our GAAP tax rate from approximately 34% to approximately 32% for full fiscal 2017. The impact on GAAP earnings per share is an increase of approximately $0.07 in the first quarter and $0.12 for the full year.
Turning to the business segments. Total Small Business revenue grew 11% for the quarter. As Brad mentioned, QuickBooks Online subscriber growth remained strong, and we exceeded our guidance for the quarter, reaching 1,638,000 subs, up 41% year-over-year. Small Business Online Ecosystem revenue grew 26% for the quarter.
As we discussed at Investor Day, we're focused on driving customer growth first, followed by online ecosystem revenue. We expect online ecosystem revenue to grow 25% to 30% this year, accelerating as the year progresses. 
QuickBooks Desktop remains a resilient and important part of our business. The first quarter was exceptionally strong for desktop units, up 23%, as unusually higher renewals from existing desktop customers were driven by operating system upgrades. Our plan does not assume this growth continues throughout the year. Desktop ecosystem revenue grew 6% in the quarter.
Moving to tax. Consumer Tax revenue for Q1 was $60 million and ProConnect revenue was $112 million. This was in line with our expectations in a seasonally light quarter. To help with your modeling, we expect second quarter Consumer Tax revenue to grow about a point faster than last year given the way the calendar falls in January 2017. And as a reminder, we expect to provide a tax unit update in late February, concurrent with our second quarter earnings release. We will also provide a final unit update in late April after the tax season ends.
We continue to take a disciplined approach to capital management, investing the cash we generate and opportunities that yield a return on investment greater than 15% over 5 years. We ended the quarter with approximately $600 million in cash and investments on our balance sheet. Our first priority for the use of that cash is investing for customer growth. When is [ph] the best use of cash, we will return shareholders via share repurchase and dividends. We repurchased 1.8 million shares in the first quarter or $192 million and $2.2 billion remains on our authorization.
The board also approved the dividend of $0.34 per share payable January 18, 2017. You can find our fiscal 2017 Q2 guidance details in our press release and on our fact sheet. We've reaffirmed our full year guidance with the one exception being higher GAAP earnings per share guidance due to the early adoption of the accounting standard update mentioned earlier. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Brad to close.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Neil. I have to say, I'm pleased with the strong start for the fiscal year, and I remain optimistic about the path we're on to grow our QuickBooks Online franchise here in the U.S. as well as in prioritized [ph] markets around the gl
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Neil. I have to say, I'm pleased with the strong start for the fiscal year, and I remain optimistic about the path we're on to grow our QuickBooks Online franchise here in the U.S. as well as in prioritized [ph] markets around the globe. 
We're building on our QBO momentum in Canada, the U.K. and Australia, and we've further expanded the category with relevant offerings, like QuickBooks Self-Employed. Our third annual QuickBooks Connect conference in late October was a great success with attendance up year-over-year, which reinforce the power of the ecosystem that is creating these indispensable connection between small businesses, accountants and developers. So with the [ph] headline, we like how we come out of the gates in Q1 and we remain focused on delivering another great year. 
So with that, Latif, let's open it up and hear what's on everyone's minds.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brent Thill of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brent Thill of UBS.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, on the Small Business segment, the operating margin was flat year-over-year. You obviously grew it in '15 to '16, a pretty nice margin improvement. And I know you don't give a lot of guidance specifically to that business. But there's been some conc
componenttext: Brad, on the Small Business segment, the operating margin was flat year-over-year. You obviously grew it in '15 to '16, a pretty nice margin improvement. And I know you don't give a lot of guidance specifically to that business. But there's been some concern as you go international that you can't maintain that operating margin expansion. Can you just walk through how you think about the segment business for Small Business on margins for the rest of the year?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brent, sure can. First of all, as we look at the company overall, you know our financial print will go out [ph] to grow the top line double-digit to grow revenue faster than expense, which gives us operating margin expansion, and that produces strong
componenttext: Yes, Brent, sure can. First of all, as we look at the company overall, you know our financial print will go out [ph] to grow the top line double-digit to grow revenue faster than expense, which gives us operating margin expansion, and that produces strong cash flow and then we invest that casual to grow the franchise either through internal investment, its acquisitions or it's returning cash to shareholders. And ultimately, as we look at the businesses, both tax businesses we like to see those business margins north of 60%. And in Small Business, given we're in an expansion mode, investing and growing category, expanding into new geographies, we like to have that in the neighborhood of 40%. I wouldn't get too caught up in the first quarter. We had some things that we've moved around last year, we had our QuickBooks Connect conference that fell on the second quarter last year. This year, it fell on the first quarter. That [indiscernible] a little bit of the marketing spend forward. But right now, we actually feel good about the overall investments that we're making and our ability to deliver the kinds of margins that we typically talk to you about.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard of Citi.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if, Brad, you could help us understand on the international side. I have to say a little bit of a turnaround or an improvement in your tone there relative to even the Analyst Day you had back in September. It sounds like some of those countr
componenttext: I'm wondering if, Brad, you could help us understand on the international side. I have to say a little bit of a turnaround or an improvement in your tone there relative to even the Analyst Day you had back in September. It sounds like some of those countries you're seeing stronger trends there. And I'm just wondering, obviously, you talked about product margin [ph]. But any more detail you could give us about why you think that's picked up a bit in some of those countries.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Walter, sure can. You're right, at Investor Day, we were pretty candid an outlet [ph] about seeing the opportunity outside the U.S. being much larger with the potential to grow faster than we were able to produce in fiscal year '16. Our teams are alr
componenttext: Yes, Walter, sure can. You're right, at Investor Day, we were pretty candid an outlet [ph] about seeing the opportunity outside the U.S. being much larger with the potential to grow faster than we were able to produce in fiscal year '16. Our teams are already on that. I'm simply the radioman. And the good news is they were working on closing out that last mile of getting the product compliant and at the levels that these countries expect. We got there for Canada, the U.K. and Australia. And as a result of that, Net Promoter Scores are going up, but we've leaned in to go-to-market activities in those countries. The team also had, and we've seen, by the way, the corresponding increase in growth from 45 up to 50. And I called out the U.K. specifically, which exited last year [ph] at 78%, now at 87%, and it's continued to build momentum. This other remaining countries have there own time line to get that last mile completed for product market fit and they're very near term that we expect to see those coming online as well. So I'm optimistic that we're on it. We know what the right levers are. And the first quarter shows that if we focus on, we can actually get the numbers moving in the direction we want. So you should hear some more optimistic in my tone now because I'm starting to see the proof points pay off.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just relative to desktop, I heard the comment on the operating system upgrades driving some of that. How much of that would you say was people who maybe recommitting more than you expected to the desktop? And obviously, the online subscribe
componenttext: Okay. And then just relative to desktop, I heard the comment on the operating system upgrades driving some of that. How much of that would you say was people who maybe recommitting more than you expected to the desktop? And obviously, the online subscribers overall this quarter were quite strong. But as we look out a couple of quarters, how does [ph] potentially more of your customers recommitting to desktop impact what you might be looking for in terms of online subs as we go out [ph] a year more as maybe some of those would have moved over?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Walter, we actually feel like we're expanding the category by having both offerings in the market. So primarily, the best talked [ph] business was the revolve of the operating system upgrade. Windows 10 drove an upgrade cycle and then the operating s
componenttext: Yes, Walter, we actually feel like we're expanding the category by having both offerings in the market. So primarily, the best talked [ph] business was the revolve of the operating system upgrade. Windows 10 drove an upgrade cycle and then the operating system upgrade the [ph] Mac. And it was about 60-40 Windows and Mac. If you pull those out, it was basically flat to down 1% without the upgraders. And so I'd say that kind of normalizes things out for us. If you look at the total customer base and you count out the way we use to, which we no longer put out on the fact sheet, those are people using at least the last 3 years version of desktop or they're buying a subscription. The total base grew in the neighborhood of 5%, and that's up from where it was when we exited last year. And then if you break that down, you mentioned QBO subs are strong, 41%. The desktop got a boot to this upgrade cycle, which pushed it up to 23%. And you put it all together and the total paying customers in this last period was up a total of 33%. So I do not see cannibalization happening. I do think we were the beneficiary of this operating system upgrades. We are going to continue to have a good quality desktop offering, but we're leaning into the cloud and the customers are choosing the cloud. So I'd say that net-net, we're growing the category.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jesse Hulsing of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jesse Hulsing of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to drill in to your expectations for payroll and payments moving forward a little bit more. Payroll subscribers accelerated. I'm curious what your thought is on -- whether that acceleration is sustainable. And I'm wondering, on the payment side,
componenttext: I wanted to drill in to your expectations for payroll and payments moving forward a little bit more. Payroll subscribers accelerated. I'm curious what your thought is on -- whether that acceleration is sustainable. And I'm wondering, on the payment side, when you start to see the impact of the invoicing products start to hit the model.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say, Jesse, first of all -- I'm sorry. We do see opportunity to continue to strengthen our performance in both payroll and payments. And the team is focused on that just like we are with our international expansion of QBO. I feel good that
componenttext: Yes, so I would say, Jesse, first of all -- I'm sorry. We do see opportunity to continue to strengthen our performance in both payroll and payments. And the team is focused on that just like we are with our international expansion of QBO. I feel good that the team knows the right levers and we're continue to optimize and improve. Currently, right now, if you look at the penetration rates into the customer base, payroll is 15% in QBO, and that compares to roughly 32% of desktop. We've got a lot of headroom there. And payments right now is in the neighborhood of 6% in penetration. And that's a little ahead of desktop. And we think that opportunity has more headroom as well. So our outlook is that we're going to continue to focus on this and we're going to continue to have you focus on the penetration numbers because that's the ultimate sign. But the payoff for us is we've been guiding subscriber growth at QBO greater than 40%, and we thought to 41 [ph] and we've been guiding QBO ecosystem revenue of between 25 and 30, and we saw it tick up to 26 in this quarter. And that's the proof of the opportunity we have if we just stay focused on those 2 numbers. We're going to see strong payroll and payments growth and strong overall FPG [ph] growth.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Weiss of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Weiss of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Sanjit Singh for Keith. I wanted to talk about [ph] some of the dynamics behind subscriber guidance or the subscriber performance this quarter. So if I recall last year, I think you had some challenges in India and there was sort of a reset from t
componenttext: This is Sanjit Singh for Keith. I wanted to talk about [ph] some of the dynamics behind subscriber guidance or the subscriber performance this quarter. So if I recall last year, I think you had some challenges in India and there was sort of a reset from the strategy there. I think Canada also, there was a change in sort of go-to-market. So I guess my question is, how much of this quarter's performance in terms of the year-over-year growth is coming off the easier comps? And then going into the second half, is it just a function of better feature, functionality driving that international growth going forward. Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great question. You're correct. Last year is we had a period where we didn't feel like our non-U.S. Growth was reflecting the kinds of opportunity that we see ahead of us. We did had 2 countries that were on a pivot, Canada and India. Canada was act
componenttext: Okay, great question. You're correct. Last year is we had a period where we didn't feel like our non-U.S. Growth was reflecting the kinds of opportunity that we see ahead of us. We did had 2 countries that were on a pivot, Canada and India. Canada was actually because we had tried to test the selling in QBO subscription in a retail box in retail stores. And what we found where we were getting units, but then they were thriving. They were driving off after a 90-day period. And so we literally didn't like the quality of the suband people got out and had to grow over. Canada has since been picking up momentum and growing. But the real upside was not just Canada. In the U.K. where we went from a 78% growth rate in Q4 to an 87% in Q1 shows that it is picking up momentum as is Australia. So I would tell you this is less about the year-over-year easy comp this is more of that product market fit and leaning to go-to-market and that's a kind of feedback we're hearing from customers. And of course, we have the other 3 countries that were getting to the last stage of product market fit as well and then we'll start to lean to those in the back half that's why we feel like our 2 million to 2.2 million target is absolutely the right target to be given.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016

componenttext: Sure, Brad, I'll take a shot. This is the. If you look at the guidance we have an Analyst Day, there are a number to this. But so far, I think the plans that we've made or playing out exactly as we expected.

componenttext: Yes. So first of all, one of the things we are continuing to do is improve the Online Payroll first use expense. Sew one of the areas that the team is leading into is make it easy for you to come in and they can contextually find additional services like payroll and payments. We did have a reclassification, which may give you a little bit of a pause in the fact sheet, of about 7,000 units that had been attributed to the QuickBooks -- it's in the Mac product, it has been attributed to the desktop. It's now been attributed to online. That's where it should have been clarified along the way. So it's given you a little bit of an additional bump. But underneath that is really strong growth. With those tens of thousands you talked about, roughly 40,000, the bulk of those is just continuing to improve the user expense and there was a 7,000 subscriber pop as a result of a reclass.

componenttext: Well, I put in total aggregate. And so I would say, overall, most of that acceleration continue to be in the U.S. where we're getting some upside with a new country expansion.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Schneeberger of Oppenheimer.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Guys, I'm going to switch it up and go over to tax. Brad, curious, with the passed act coming up in this upcoming tax season, just curious how you think that's going to shape early season filing behavior? And it looks the store front guys are going to hav
componenttext: Guys, I'm going to switch it up and go over to tax. Brad, curious, with the passed act coming up in this upcoming tax season, just curious how you think that's going to shape early season filing behavior? And it looks the store front guys are going to have some new refund advance products. Just your thoughts on how you might compete with that.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Scott. Every year is an exciting year in tax. Our team is geared up. We've got some really cool product innovations and go-to-market campaigns. And the team's attention for this is inside for that first whistle to blow. Obviously, we do have the tax
componenttext: Sure, Scott. Every year is an exciting year in tax. Our team is geared up. We've got some really cool product innovations and go-to-market campaigns. And the team's attention for this is inside for that first whistle to blow. Obviously, we do have the tax active this year. Those are people have earned income tax credit for those who actually have a child credit. The IRS working with the rest of the industry has decided to hold those refunds until February 15, which helps us increase W-2 verification and prevent fraud. We've been very supportive of that. We believe fundamentally, though, that the IRS and the industry still leaning in. So we're 9 out of 10 returns will actually get the refund back in 21 days. So we don't see a material change in the seasonality, but we're fully prepared to help those people get their money. In terms of some of the stores leading a new those recent anticipation alone, we pulled out of that business, as you know, more than a decade ago. And you can go back and track our results while they have had refund anticipation loans and we have not, we've been able to manage their growth to do-it-yourself category into gain market share over that period of time. So we fundamentally don't see a shift in any sort of method behavior based upon history, and we are fully prepared to help those people of income tax credit got their refund.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on a follow-up. What are you expecting for industry growth this year in tax with the IRS? And just your thoughts on potential influence this year or looking out a few years given the results of the election.
componenttext: Just on a follow-up. What are you expecting for industry growth this year in tax with the IRS? And just your thoughts on potential influence this year or looking out a few years given the results of the election.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Well, our assumptions right now are in the neighborhood of 1% to 2%. We typically are in the 0% to 1% range. Right now, everyone in our business, as well some of the industry, suggested it might be a little bit more robust this year. So I'm to
componenttext: All right. Well, our assumptions right now are in the neighborhood of 1% to 2%. We typically are in the 0% to 1% range. Right now, everyone in our business, as well some of the industry, suggested it might be a little bit more robust this year. So I'm to sea somewhere in that ZIP Code of 1 to 2. In terms of what's happened to the election, you know as well as we do, we've been in this business now for over 3 decades. And we hear a lot of really good intense and then also what happens when the new President and Congress get in is what can we actually turn that into. And so I would tell you that we remain dedicated supportive of things like tax simplification. We've been big supporters of that and very vocal about it. We're very supported and very vocal about voluntary compliance and we're also big fans of putting more money in the pockets of small businesses and consumers, paying less tax. So far, that's sort of what we're hearing. But we have got into January yet. We don't have the new president elect in office and the new Congress. So right now, which is prepared to do what we always did set the best part of the market and trying to win the customer one customer at a time.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Nemeroff of Crdit Suisse.

And if so, do you expect any back in Q3 from that SE product with tax?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, Michael, I'll take the first one and give Neil the second one, as you had asked. In terms of an individual partners subscriber contribution, we haven't provided any of the breakdown. But I can bring it up to an overall impact. We know when one of ou
componenttext: Okay, Michael, I'll take the first one and give Neil the second one, as you had asked. In terms of an individual partners subscriber contribution, we haven't provided any of the breakdown. But I can bring it up to an overall impact. We know when one of our Small Business customers attached to a third-party product that increases the retention of QBO 10 points. And so we are big fans of these partnerships that we're now because we think it improve that only the customer experience so they can solve additional problem, but also it helps build more retention into QBO, which is one of the biggest levers we have in terms of recurring revenue. So that s sort of probably look at it as an aggregate level. You want to talk about the bundle?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're excited about the TurboTax Online, QuickBooks Self-Employed bundle, and we'll see how that plays out. The way we were going to treat that, Michael, isn't that we're watching carefully to see how those customers to engage with QuickBooks Self-E
componenttext: Sure. We're excited about the TurboTax Online, QuickBooks Self-Employed bundle, and we'll see how that plays out. The way we were going to treat that, Michael, isn't that we're watching carefully to see how those customers to engage with QuickBooks Self-Employed after tax season is over. And so for those customers who are active, and we use the QuickBooks product, we will defer and allocate part of that revenue over the 12-month subscription period that they are entitled to use QuickBooks SE. We have some assumptions around what those utilization rates are that are baked into our guidance for the year, both for units and for revenue. Certainly, if we see that play out differently and we see the guidance change either by quarter or for the full year, we'll let you know. But for those customers who do activate and use the self-employed component of the bundle after tax season is over, we will be allocating a portion of what they paid over the 12-month period that the subscription covers. But that's reflected in the guidance. [indiscernible] for the full year and we come back to give a guidance for Q3 and Q4, we'll have those assumptions baked in.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Yun Kim of Brean Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Yun Kim of Brean Capital.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats on a solid QBO subnumber, Brad. I guess, last on the overall strong QBO self employed performance, is that your core U.S. QBO subs when you exclude the self-employed version, actually grew stronger the quarter for the first time in a while, espec
componenttext: Congrats on a solid QBO subnumber, Brad. I guess, last on the overall strong QBO self employed performance, is that your core U.S. QBO subs when you exclude the self-employed version, actually grew stronger the quarter for the first time in a while, especially off somewhat of a like slowdown last year. I know it's just in one quarter. But do you expect that part of the core traditional QBO subs to rebound this year? Does the traditional QBO sub adds, is that heavily influenced by what you're doing currently with the focusing on the accounting programs and whatnot?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you, Yun Kim. First of all, I really appreciate that you called out the U.S. QBO subs number. We're also very please with those results. And we think there's more in the barrel for us to get there. In fact, we talked about these innovations tha
componenttext:
Yes, thank you, Yun Kim. First of all, I really appreciate that you called out the U.S. QBO subs number. We're also very please with those results. And we think there's more in the barrel for us to get there. In fact, we talked about these innovations that really kicked in for the second half. As talking about our first use experience.
The ability for a first-time user to come in and get to their P&L in less than 5 mins we think will be really cool for final conversion. The other thing is invoicing and tracking capability. Think about that like the ability to have uber or FedEx tracking for your invoice, where you literally can go in on your phone, you send the invoice and it lets you know it's been opened, then it lets you know if it's been paid and then it will send you an alter when factored into your account. And that's getting Small Businesses paid 15 days faster, over 2 weeks faster. And then we have other components for adding in as well as Google Calendar. The ability for someone to have their appointment in Google Calendar and then click on it, send an invoice and have a flow ride into QuickBooks and get paid. Those are all elements that not only help QBO outside the U.S, but what help accelerate our growth rate in the U.S. So we think there is fundamental strength in the United States. We're also looking at these non-U.S. markets and we think these innovations would only add some fuel to that fire.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kartik Mehta of Northcoast Research.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, I wanted to ask a little bit about tax and the success you've had with Absolute Zero. As you're seeing more competition in the marketplace, whether it's this route funding or your competitors kind of going to an Absolute Zero. Do you think you have
componenttext: Brad, I wanted to ask a little bit about tax and the success you've had with Absolute Zero. As you're seeing more competition in the marketplace, whether it's this route funding or your competitors kind of going to an Absolute Zero. Do you think you have to expand that program to even include more forms to attract customers? Or do you think where you are and the strategy you're taking doesn't have to change?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kartik, thank you for the question. We've been on a multiyear journey to reimagine the tax preparation process. And our goal is to eliminate 6 billion hours of tax. You don't even have to answer questions. And last year, we knocked off 40% of the time it
componenttext: Kartik, thank you for the question. We've been on a multiyear journey to reimagine the tax preparation process. And our goal is to eliminate 6 billion hours of tax. You don't even have to answer questions. And last year, we knocked off 40% of the time it takes to file an average tax return in TurboTax, and we leaned into a leading mobile offering that no one else has. And I think that is the source of our advantage and our market share gains. Just to give you a case in point. Last year, we had a competitor who matched Absolute Zero, not only matched it in terms of the product lineup, but they even kept it out in the market longer than we did. We ended the program March 31. They carried it through the end of tax season and we still took share. So my fundamental belief is that price is not a durable competitive advantage neither our promotions. It is the product and the experience you create for the customer. And we've got 3 or 4-year headstart on the players in the market by basically reimagining this next chapter. The second piece on the I mentioned a few minutes ago, we fought out of that business more than a decade ago. And you can go back and look, and I know you have spent  time talking about this. You can look at the do-it-yourself category group. You can also look at our market share gains within that category despite not having a refund anticipation loan. So we don't believe we're dealing with anything differently this year in terms of a row than we have for the last 10 to 12 years, and we're fundamentally leaning to the product experience. When we think it's going to be another competitive season but I like what our team and looking forward to the January 1 kickoff.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Brad, I just want to go back to what you're saying about the path act to make sure I understood. Were you saying that even with the path act, you anticipate that most refunds will be around the same time that customers are down last year or what
componenttext: And then, Brad, I just want to go back to what you're saying about the path act to make sure I understood. Were you saying that even with the path act, you anticipate that most refunds will be around the same time that customers are down last year or what's the point that the timing of the difference whenever the higher starts processing will be the same?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the overall -- if you put all $150 million returns at the IRS will process roughly in a year, 9 out of 10 with those will actually get a refund back in 21 days or less. The Path Act does actually narrow in on those who do earn income tax credit and
componenttext:
Well, the overall -- if you put all $150 million returns at the IRS will process roughly in a year, 9 out of 10 with those will actually get a refund back in 21 days or less. The Path Act does actually narrow in on those who do earn income tax credit and those who have a child credit, and they are going to have that refund held back until February 15. So for those who come in early, have those qualifications and are hoping to get their refund sooner, they are going to be held back for a week or 2 here until February 15. So that will be an impacted group. But our goal is to help those individuals understand the status of the refund, keep them apprised and make sure they have a great experience. But fundamentally, I don't think this is going to shape or shift the overall tax season, and that's our philosophy going in and we just want to make sure we're there for these customers.
And I don't think the refund anticipation loan, honestly, is going to shape the overall system. I think it's going to be a period of time and then we're going to get past that.

The second piece is we had QuickBooks Self-Employed that's going to add more fuel to the fire in the United States. And of course, we do have desktop migrators. In the first quarter, we got a little bit of a bump there with these operating system upgrades. The migrators were up about 50% year-over-year. Last year, they were up 25% overall. So there's always a little bit of tailwind as well. But we feel good about the United States and the QBO subs outlook as we look for the balance of the fiscal year.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you give us a little more on the quarterly shift. You said 1 point of tax into the January quarter. And can you talk about what the -- is that just taken out of the next quarter? I mean, 1% of sort of what?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim, this is Neil. The way the calendar falls in 2017, the 31st of January is actually on a Tuesday. In 2016, it fell on a Saturday. And we know a lot of people do their tax returns over the weekend and actually get -- actually file them on Monday. So whe
componenttext: Jim, this is Neil. The way the calendar falls in 2017, the 31st of January is actually on a Tuesday. In 2016, it fell on a Saturday. And we know a lot of people do their tax returns over the weekend and actually get -- actually file them on Monday. So when we factor in 2017, getting the full 31 days of January into our first quarter, it would make our growth rate the way we look at it, for our TurboTax revenue in Q2 about 1 point or so higher than the growth rate we posted for last year. So I know getting seasonality right on Consumer Tax is always a challenge for you guys. And so just to let you know, the way we see it playing out is we would see our second quarter growth in Consumer Tax about a point or so better than the growth rate we posted last year just because there are a couple of extra days customers can actually file their returns, taking in the weekend into account and getting into our Q2. It's a total shift from Q3 to Q2. It doesn't change the full year outlook, doesn't mean that more taxpayers or anything like that. It's just an anomaly with the way the calendar falls and the way consumers have time to work on their returns.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just to clarify. So last year, there was a shift, a big shift, so you had a big growth of Consumer Tax due to the shift back. So you're saying it's going to be 1% more than the 30% last year?
componenttext: But just to clarify. So last year, there was a shift, a big shift, so you had a big growth of Consumer Tax due to the shift back. So you're saying it's going to be 1% more than the 30% last year?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, last year was actually a return to more normalized trends. After the year before that, having a delay with the IRS opening to receive returns. So be kind of view '16 as being a more normalized Q2 for us in terms of Consumer Tax revenue. And so, yes,
componenttext: Yes, last year was actually a return to more normalized trends. After the year before that, having a delay with the IRS opening to receive returns. So be kind of view '16 as being a more normalized Q2 for us in terms of Consumer Tax revenue. And so, yes, it's a point or so above that.

componenttext: Well, first of all, we do agree with you. We think tax simplification will drive more people to basically do the taxes themselves. In terms of weather it to drive a's be lower, there are other value-added services that we provide that basically help consumers. Say, hey, I'm willing to pay for that particular service. So we don't fundamentally believe that it ultimately need to you to our lower ASP. Basically puts more energy into what are the other services you can offer a tax filer or if they willing to pay more for. And those are the things that our team has been leaning into over the last couple of years. So I would agree with the first concept. We don't believe it naturally suppresses ASP on the second concept. It just puts more innovation in the areas beyond the actual tax filing itself.

componenttext: I'm asking the question on the half of cash. Just on the online payment and online payroll. Can you talk about the attach rates that you're seeing right now relative to fiscal year 2016? And where do you see that going, especially given the growth in SE. Do you see an inflection point that you can actually see the attach rate going from here?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Shankar. First of all, let me start with the reason why we try to talk about penetration rate is because we think that's in the ultimate pay off and that needs to ecosystem revenue growth. So right now, there's 2 big numbers that we look at. One is
componenttext: Sure, Shankar. First of all, let me start with the reason why we try to talk about penetration rate is because we think that's in the ultimate pay off and that needs to ecosystem revenue growth. So right now, there's 2 big numbers that we look at. One is what's the QBO ecosystem revenue growth? And it's 26%, which is up a little from last quarter. And then the second peace is what are the penetration rates that payroll and payments into the QuickBooks Online base? And those are currently 15% for payroll and 6% for payment. Lots of upside opportunity but good stream. Now one of the leading indicators is an attach rate, which I to pull back on that because attach rates get muddied. They get modded because QuickBooks Self-Employed, by definition, does not have a payroll. They don't have anyplace but they go into the QuickBooks Online base. And if you start doing the math, you'll say, oh, we got a problem here. Attach is going down, but it's not. It's QuickBooks Self-Employed is coming a bigger part of the mix. The other thing that jumps off if you talk about attach rates is we will get promotions this time whether it say buy now without a bundle or it might even be something with a accountant to in turn and get the consumer start think about payroll and payments down the road, and then we can muddied the water. But I'll answer the question what are the attach rates right now. It was 15% in the quarter for payroll and it was 9% for payment that you have to put that caveat next to it, which is we had a big mix of QuickBooks Self-Employed and we also had some growth outside the United States where we don't yet offer for payroll and payments. And those numbers are going to make the attach rates with a little bit distorted. So I hope you stay focused on 26% ecosystem growth, which is up from 25%. That's the real help indicator.

componenttext: Well, if you go back and look at what it would take for us to deliver the 2 million to 2.2 million subs, that would take subscriber growth between 32% to 45%. And right now, we just caught 41% in Q1, which is an uptick from last quarter. And we did walk through some of the innovations we have and the market no that we've introduced that we think gives us confidence that we're going to be able to deliver that 2 million to 2.2 million. It's still too early in the game for us to say, hey, our confidence is now that we're going to go pass it 2 million to 2.2 million. But hopefully, gives you enough assurances to say you can see momentum in the base growing and you could hear the innovations coming. And honestly, it gives me a little bit of confidence to hear that the question is now, are going to hit the number? Now it's actually are you going to exceed the number? We feel good about the things in the pipeline, but it's too early for us to say that we're going to be looking at raising guidance.

Good afternoon. My name is Latif, and I will be your conference facilitator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to Intuit's First Quarter 2017 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Jerry Natoli, Intuit's Vice President of Finance and Treasurer. Mr. Natoli?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Latif. Good afternoon, and welcome to Intuit's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. I'm here with Brad Smith, our Chairman and CEO; and Neil Williams, our CFO.Before we start, I'd like to remind everyone that our remarks will include forwa
componenttext:
Thanks, Latif. Good afternoon, and welcome to Intuit's First Quarter Fiscal 2017 Conference Call. I'm here with Brad Smith, our Chairman and CEO; and Neil Williams, our CFO.
Before we start, I'd like to remind everyone that our remarks will include forward-looking statements. There are a number of factors that could cause Intuit's results to differ materially from our expectations. You can learn more about these risks in the press release we issued earlier this afternoon, our Form 10-K for fiscal 2016 and our other SEC filings. All of those documents are available on the Investor Relations page of Intuit's website at intuit.com. We assume no obligation to update any forward-looking statement.
Some of the numbers in these remarks are presented on a non-GAAP basis. We've reconciled the comparable GAAP and non-GAAP numbers in today's press release. Unless otherwise noted, all growth rates refer to the current period versus the comparable prior year period, and the business metrics and associated growth rates refer to worldwide business metrics.
A copy of our prepared remarks and supplemental financial information will be available on our website after this call ends. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Brad.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Jerry. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Fiscal 2017 is off to a strong start, and we're building on the momentum that we developed in fiscal 2016. In the first quarter, we grew revenue 9%, exceeded our QuickBook
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Jerry. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Fiscal 2017 is off to a strong start, and we're building on the momentum that we developed in fiscal 2016. 
In the first quarter, we grew revenue 9%, exceeded our QuickBooks Online subscriber guidance and we beat our overall financial targets. With that backdrop, let me begin by sharing a few reflections on our business performance, and I'll start with Small Business. 
QuickBooks Online continue to gain traction as we pursue a large global market opportunity. Our goal remains to be the operating system behind Small Business success, helping small businesses save time and improve their cash flow, so that they thrive when times are good and they remain resilient when times are tough.
Total QBO subscribers grew 41% in the quarter to more than 1.6 million subs. We drove acceleration in our Small Business market outside the U.S., where QuickBooks Online grew 50% to 323,000 subscribers, up from 45% in fiscal 2016. The increase came in Canada, the U.K. and Australia with subscriber growth in the U.K. accelerating to 87%, which was up from 78%. We continue to focus our efforts on improving the product market fit in the remaining countries, which include India, Brazil and France, and we'll report more on our progress with these efforts in the coming quarters. 
QuickBooks Self-Employed is also contributing to the acceleration of subscribers. Roughly 110,000 of our QBO subscribers are using QuickBooks Self-Employed. This is compared to 85,000 last quarter and 35,000 a year ago. We've now launched QuickBooks Self-Employed in the U.K. and in Australia as well. 
I'm encouraged by the start in our Small Business Group, but I also expect our momentum to continue accelerating in the second half as we drive towards our QBO subscriber target of 2 million to 2.2 million subs for the full fiscal year. I'm confident in this acceleration because of the innovation that we have coming to market, including improvements in the core QBO platform that simplify the first use experience, including enabling small businesses to generate their first profit and loss statement in less than 5 minutes. 
We've also introduced a new smart invoicing capability that allows for real-time tracking of the invoice status in both QuickBooks Online and QuickBooks Self-Employed. We've also enhanced the QuickBooks Self-Employed user experience with the ability to now receive payments on mobile devices and always on mileage tracking. And finally, our recently introduced partnership with Google enable the seamless integration between QuickBooks Online and Google Calendar. 
Based on the strong product market fit that we have with Canada, the U.K. and Australia, we're leaning into greater go-to-market activity behind QBO in these countries. It's these factors that support our confidence in the continued acceleration of QBO subscribers in the back half of the fiscal year.
With that overview on Small Business, let's talk tax. We're gearing up for another exciting tax season in TurboTax by continuing our multiyear investment and product innovation. Those product innovations are focused on reimagining the tax preparation process while driving customer growth and increasing market share. We also continue to promote a set of best practices and standards within the industry that enable the IRS and the state to improve the ability to combat tax fraud. 
In ProConnect, we're focused on serving multiservice accountants to do both books and taxes for their customers. Our goal is to be the operating system behind the accountant's successes as well. In service to this goal, we're providing one location within QuickBooks Online for accountant, where the accountant can access all of their workflows.
Several exciting innovations are underway to begin to leverage the capabilities that we've developed in TurboTax within our accountant's offering, including increasing the number of documents that can be automatically uploaded, which reduces data entry. 
We expect these innovations to help us further strengthen our accountant relationships by helping drive QuickBooks growth over time. So across the board, we're off to a strong start in all of our businesses. And with that, let me turn it over to Neil to walk you through the financials.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brad, and good afternoon, everyone. For the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we delivered revenue of $778 million, up 9%; GAAP operating loss of $61 million; non-GAAP operating income of $32 million; a GAAP loss per share of $0.12; and non-GAAP dilut
componenttext:
Thanks, Brad, and good afternoon, everyone. For the first quarter of fiscal 2017, we delivered revenue of $778 million, up 9%; GAAP operating loss of $61 million; non-GAAP operating income of $32 million; a GAAP loss per share of $0.12; and non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.06. Note that our GAAP earnings per share includes the impact of the early adoption of the new accounting standard update for share-based compensation. This update requires excess tax benefits realized upon the settlement of a share-based compensation award to flow through the earning statement instead of the balance sheet.
We expect this accounting change to reduce our GAAP tax rate from approximately 34% to approximately 32% for full fiscal 2017. The impact on GAAP earnings per share is an increase of approximately $0.07 in the first quarter and $0.12 for the full year.
Turning to the business segments. Total Small Business revenue grew 11% for the quarter. As Brad mentioned, QuickBooks Online subscriber growth remained strong, and we exceeded our guidance for the quarter, reaching 1,638,000 subs, up 41% year-over-year. Small Business Online Ecosystem revenue grew 26% for the quarter.
As we discussed at Investor Day, we're focused on driving customer growth first, followed by online ecosystem revenue. We expect online ecosystem revenue to grow 25% to 30% this year, accelerating as the year progresses. 
QuickBooks Desktop remains a resilient and important part of our business. The first quarter was exceptionally strong for desktop units, up 23%, as unusually higher renewals from existing desktop customers were driven by operating system upgrades. Our plan does not assume this growth continues throughout the year. Desktop ecosystem revenue grew 6% in the quarter.
Moving to tax. Consumer Tax revenue for Q1 was $60 million and ProConnect revenue was $112 million. This was in line with our expectations in a seasonally light quarter. To help with your modeling, we expect second quarter Consumer Tax revenue to grow about a point faster than last year, given the way the calendar falls in January 2017. And as a reminder, we expect to provide a tax unit update in late February, concurrent with our second quarter earnings release. We will also provide a final unit update in late April after the tax season ends.
We continue to take a disciplined approach to capital management, investing the cash we generate in opportunities that yield a return on investment greater than 15% over 5 years. We ended the quarter with approximately $600 million in cash and investments on our balance sheet. Our first priority for the use of that cash is investing for customer growth. When it's the best use of cash, we will return cash to shareholders via share repurchase and dividends. We repurchased 1.8 million shares in the first quarter for $192 million and $2.2 billion remains on our authorization. The board also approved the dividend of $0.34 per share payable January 18, 2017. 
You can find our fiscal 2017 Q2 guidance details in our press release and on our fact sheet. We reaffirmed our full year guidance with the one exception being higher GAAP earnings per share guidance due to the early adoption of the accounting standard update mentioned earlier. 
And with that, I'll turn it back to Brad to close.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Neil. I have to say, I'm pleased with the strong start for the fiscal year, and I remain optimistic about the path we're on to grow our QuickBooks Online franchise here in the U.S. as well as in prioritized markets around the globe.
componenttext:
All right. Thank you, Neil. I have to say, I'm pleased with the strong start for the fiscal year, and I remain optimistic about the path we're on to grow our QuickBooks Online franchise here in the U.S. as well as in prioritized markets around the globe. 
We're building on our QBO momentum in Canada, the U.K. and Australia, and we've further expanded the category with relevant offerings, like QuickBooks Self-Employed. Our third annual QuickBooks Connect conference in late October was a great success with attendance up year-over-year, which reinforce the power of the ecosystem that is creating this indispensable connection between small businesses, accountants and developers. So in a headline, we like how we've come out of the gates in Q1, and we remain focused on delivering another great year. 
So with that, Latif, let's open it up and hear what's on everyone's minds.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brent Thill of UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brent Thill of UBS.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, on the Small Business segment, the operating margin was flat year-over-year. You obviously grew it in '15 to '16, a pretty nice margin improvement. And I know you don't give a lot of guidance specifically to that business. But there's been some conc
componenttext: Brad, on the Small Business segment, the operating margin was flat year-over-year. You obviously grew it in '15 to '16, a pretty nice margin improvement. And I know you don't give a lot of guidance specifically to that business. But there's been some concern as you go international that you can't maintain that operating margin expansion. Can you just walk through how you think about the segment business for Small Business on margins for the rest of the year?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brent, sure can. First of all, as we look at the company overall, you know our financial principles are to grow the top line double-digit to grow revenue faster than expense, which gives us operating margin expansion, and that produces strong cash fl
componenttext: Yes, Brent, sure can. First of all, as we look at the company overall, you know our financial principles are to grow the top line double-digit to grow revenue faster than expense, which gives us operating margin expansion, and that produces strong cash flow and then we invest that casual to grow the franchise either through internal investment, its acquisitions or it's returning cash to shareholders. And ultimately, as we look at the businesses, both tax businesses we like to see those business margins north of 60%. And in Small Business, given we're in an expansion mode, investing and growing category, expanding into new geographies, we like to have that in the neighborhood of 40%. I wouldn't get too caught up in the first quarter. We had some things that we've moved around last year, we had our QuickBooks Connect conference that fell on the second quarter last year. This year, it fell on the first quarter. So that brought a little bit of the marketing spend forward. But right now, we actually feel good about the overall investments that we're making and our ability to deliver the kinds of margins that we typically talk to you about.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Walter Pritchard of Citi.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if, Brad, you could help us understand on the international side. I have to say a little bit of a turnaround or an improvement in your tone there relative to even the Analyst Day you had back in September. It sounds like some of those countr
componenttext: I'm wondering if, Brad, you could help us understand on the international side. I have to say a little bit of a turnaround or an improvement in your tone there relative to even the Analyst Day you had back in September. It sounds like some of those countries you're seeing stronger trends there. And I'm just wondering, obviously, you talked about product market fit. But any more detail you could give us about why you think that's picked up a bit in some of those countries.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Walter, sure can. You're right, at Investor Day, we were pretty candid and I was about seeing the opportunity outside the U.S. being much larger with the potential to grow faster than we were able to produce in fiscal year '16. Our teams are already
componenttext: Yes, Walter, sure can. You're right, at Investor Day, we were pretty candid and I was about seeing the opportunity outside the U.S. being much larger with the potential to grow faster than we were able to produce in fiscal year '16. Our teams are already on that. I'm simply the radioman. And the good news is they were working on closing out that last mile of getting the product compliant and at the levels that these countries expect. We got there for Canada, the U.K. and Australia. And as a result of that, Net Promoter Scores are going up, but we've leaned in to go-to-market activities in those countries. The team also had, and we've seen, by the way, the corresponding increase in growth from 45 up to 50. And I called out the U.K. specifically, which exited last year 78%, now it's 87%, and it's continued to build momentum. This other remaining countries have their own time line to get that last mile completed for product market fit and they're very near term that we expect to see those coming online as well. So I'm optimistic that we're on it. We know what the right levers are. And the first quarter shows that if we focus on, we can actually get the numbers moving in the direction we want. So you should hear some more optimistic in my tone now because I'm starting to see the proof points pay off.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just relative to desktop, I heard the comment on the operating system upgrades driving some of that. How much of that would you say was people who maybe recommitting more than you expected to the desktop? And obviously, the online subscribe
componenttext: Okay. And then just relative to desktop, I heard the comment on the operating system upgrades driving some of that. How much of that would you say was people who maybe recommitting more than you expected to the desktop? And obviously, the online subscribers overall this quarter were quite strong. But as we look out a couple of quarters, how does potentially more of your customers recommitting to desktop impact what you might be looking for in terms of online subs as we go out a year more as maybe some of those would have moved over?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Walter, we actually feel like we're expanding the category by having both offerings in the market. So primarily, the desktop business was the result of the operating system upgrade. Windows 10 drove an upgrade cycle and then the operating system upgr
componenttext: Yes, Walter, we actually feel like we're expanding the category by having both offerings in the market. So primarily, the desktop business was the result of the operating system upgrade. Windows 10 drove an upgrade cycle and then the operating system upgrade in Mac. And it was about 60-40 Windows and Mac. If you pull those out, it was basically flat to down 1% without the upgraders. And so I'd say that kind of normalizes things out for us. If you look at the total customer base and you count out the way we use to, which we no longer put out on the fact sheet, those are people using at least the last 3 years version of desktop or they're buying a subscription. The total base grew in the neighborhood of 5%, and that's up from where it was when we exited last year. And then if you break that down, you mentioned QBO subs are strong, 41%. The desktop got a boot to this upgrade cycle, which pushed it up to 23%. And you put it all together and the total paying customers in this last period was up a total of 33%. So I do not see cannibalization happening. I do think we were the beneficiary of this operating system upgrades. We are going to continue to have a good quality desktop offering, but we're leaning into the cloud and the customers are choosing the cloud. So I'd say that net-net, we're growing the category.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jesse Hulsing of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jesse Hulsing of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to drill in to your expectations for payroll and payments moving forward a little bit more. Payroll subscribers accelerated. I'm curious what your thought is on -- whether that acceleration is sustainable. And I'm wondering, on the payment side,
componenttext: I wanted to drill in to your expectations for payroll and payments moving forward a little bit more. Payroll subscribers accelerated. I'm curious what your thought is on -- whether that acceleration is sustainable. And I'm wondering, on the payment side, when you start to see the impact of the invoicing products start to hit the model.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say, Jesse, first of all -- I'm sorry. We do see opportunity to continue to strengthen our performance in both payroll and payments. And the team is focused on that just like we are with our international expansion of QBO. I feel good that
componenttext: Yes, so I would say, Jesse, first of all -- I'm sorry. We do see opportunity to continue to strengthen our performance in both payroll and payments. And the team is focused on that just like we are with our international expansion of QBO. I feel good that the team knows the right levers and we're continuing to optimize and improve. Currently, right now, if you look at the penetration rates into the customer base, payroll is 15% in QBO, and that compares to roughly 32% of desktop. We've got a lot of headroom there. And payments right now is in the neighborhood of 6% in penetration. And that's a little ahead of desktop. And we think that opportunity has more headroom as well. So our outlook is that we're going to continue to focus on this and we're going to continue to have you focus on the penetration numbers because that's the ultimate sign. But the payoff for us is we've been guiding subscriber growth at QBO greater than 40, and we saw it uptick to 41 and we've been guiding QBO ecosystem revenue of between 25 and 30, and we saw it tick up to 26 in this quarter. And that's the proof of the opportunity we have if we just stay focused on those 2 numbers. We're going to see strong payroll and payments growth and strong overall FPG [ph] growth.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Keith Weiss of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Keith Weiss of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Sanjit Singh for Keith. I wanted to toggle back to some of the dynamics behind subscriber guidance or the subscriber performance this quarter. So if I recall last year, I think you had some challenges in India and there was sort of a reset from th
componenttext: This is Sanjit Singh for Keith. I wanted to toggle back to some of the dynamics behind subscriber guidance or the subscriber performance this quarter. So if I recall last year, I think you had some challenges in India and there was sort of a reset from the strategy there. I think Canada also, there was a change in sort of go to market. So I guess my question is, how much of this quarter's performance in terms of the year-over-year growth is coming off the easier comps? And then going into the second half, is it just a function of better feature functionality driving that international growth going forward? Is that the right way to think about it?

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great question. You're correct. Last year is we had a period where we didn't feel like our non-U.S. Growth was reflecting the kinds of opportunity that we see ahead of us. We did have 2 countries that were on a pivot, Canada and India. Canada was ac
componenttext: Okay, great question. You're correct. Last year is we had a period where we didn't feel like our non-U.S. Growth was reflecting the kinds of opportunity that we see ahead of us. We did have 2 countries that were on a pivot, Canada and India. Canada was actually because we had tried to test the selling in QBO subscription in a retail box in retail stores. And what we found were we were getting units, but then they weren't thriving. They were dropping off after a 90-day period. And so we literally didn't like the quality of the sub and we pull that out and we had to grow over. Canada has since been picking up momentum and growing. But the real upside here was not just Canada. In the U.K. where we went from a 78% growth rate in Q4 to an 87% in Q1 shows that it's picking up momentum as is Australia. So I would tell you this is less about a year-over-year easy comp and this is more about that product market fit and leaning into go-to-market and that's the kind of feedback we're hearing from customers. And of course, we have the other 3 countries that we're getting to the last stage of product market fit as well and then we'll start to lean into those in the back half and that's why we feel like our 2 million to 2.2 million target is absolutely the right target to be given.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just a quick follow-up and an update on maybe some of the unit economic metrics. So if we look at -- is there any comments you have on renewal rates in terms of QBO and maybe by segment? And then also with respect to ASPs. I noticed on the
componenttext: Understood. And just a quick follow-up and an update on maybe some of the unit economic metrics. componenttext: Sure, Brad, I'll give this a shot. It's Neil. If you go back to the guidance we gave and the transition we had at Analyst Day, there are a number of moving parts in this. Clearly, QuickBooks Self-Employed as Brad mentioned is growing quite nicely and, which is overall providing some downward pressure on our overall ASPs. We did implement a price change in QBO in the U.S. midway through the first quarter this year, which had a little bit of impact and will impact for the balance of the year. It's a very modest price increase, but it's on a fairly large base. And as we've already talked about, we're probably focused more on retention and driving the value of the accounting product outside of the U.S. where you know we don't have the same potential for payroll and payments attachment we do in the U.S. at this time. But first quarter was good to us. It's like we're very much on track with our expectations. You saw the acceleration in the Online Ecosystem revenue by a point. So it's early in the year. But so far, I think the plans that we've made are playing out exactly as we expected.

componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, one of the things we are continuing to do is improve the Online Payroll first-use experience. So one of the areas that the  team's leaned into is make it easy for you to come in and then contextually find additional services like pay
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, one of the things we are continuing to do is improve the Online Payroll first-use experience. So one of the areas that the  team's leaned into is make it easy for you to come in and then contextually find additional services like payroll and payments. We did have a reclassification, which may give you a little bit of a pause in the fact sheet, of about 7,000 units that have been attributed to the QuickBooks -- it's in the Mac product, it had been attributed to the desktop. It's now been attributed to online. That's where it should have been clarified along the way. So it's given you a little bit of an additional bump. But underneath that is really strong growth. With those tens of thousands you talked about, roughly 40,000, the bulk of those is just continuing to improve the user expense and there was a 7,000 subscriber pop as a result of a reclass.

componenttext: Well, I put in total aggregate. We weren't in the market for the full first quarter in the U.K. and Australia. That's been in more recent weeks, but the early results had been very positive. And so I would say, overall, most of that acceleration continue to be in the U.S. where we're getting some upside with a new country expansion.

headline: Intuit Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
